Not much at all. I thought this would be a cool course learning practical stuff about energy that I could use in real life, but this was not the case at all. First we did a lot of unit conversions, and then we did a lot of random statistics (like what percent of what kind of use is from which fuel source), then we did a lot of boring earth science that nobody in the energy industry cares about, then we did some basic stuff on emissions and climate change. The last parts were the most interesting, but the lecture style was so boring that I don't think people learned as much as they could have. So I feel utterly disappointed by what I learned in what is a core course for the G&G major. This course is full of athletes, and rightly so: this is not to dis the athletes, because I know how busy your schedules are, but clearly this course is a gut science, so if you are looking to learn things, go elsewhere.

Professor Oristaglio is really nice and has come up with a strong curriculum that is easily accessible by non-science majors. The problem sets varied a lot in the time they took, but I appreciated the skills they encouraged me to exercise.

Strengths: well I guess for the most part the problem sets aren't too difficult. And you get 75 minutes twice a week to stare at whatever you want on your computer. Oristaglio is very nice, fair, and good at responding to emails and answering questions. I do think he cares, I just think the course is ineffective. 

Weaknesses: Lecture style is very dry and boring. This is why everyone is staring at their computers instead of paying attention. The material in class was not really related to the problem sets, nor (apparently) to the exams, so there was little reason to pay attention. Therefore, the entirely of my learning from the course came from teaching myself the material for the problem sets and the exams.

Course material is uninteresting. I did not really want a geology lecture, I wanted to learn about fossil fuels. I think the curriculum could be made better by scaling way back the earth science side (give us a primer, but this isn't a structural geology or mineralogy course) and then teaching us more about how the energy actually works. How do the power plants work? How big are the turbines and how does their turning generate power? How is this power transmitted to the grid? What is the grid? What is the efficiency per mile? Where do they put power plants and why? As thrilled as I am to try to remember in which geologic period the most oil came to the trap or whatever (I don't even know), why not make this a useful course about how energy works? Either that, or rename it to make it an actual geology course. Ron Smith teaches in renewable energy about the stuff I've mentioned above (like how do we calculate energy output per wind or hydro turbine based on its size and flow rate of the air/water?)... perhaps taking some pages from his book would improve the curriculum.

See, if you want to learn something, certainly not. And certainly not if you're doing it for energy studies, unless you're really into geology (but at a pretty elementary level and with a lot of boring stuff mixed in and with really boring lectures). If you are a G&G major, I imagine you'd be incredibly disappointed by how little you're learn in what is a core course for the major. And if you're just looking for a science credit, then I guess this isn't the worst option since it's like not a huge onslaught of work, but please please consider taking something in which you'll learn literally something (it would be a pity not to for this much money per course, and didn't you come here to learn something?), because I don't think I'll remember much at all from this course--I could probably have learned everything I did in a two-hour condensed lecture. Oristaglio is very nice, but he's an unengaging lecturer, attention during lectures was staggeringly low, and the topics were not interesting to anyone--not energy enough for energy scholars and not hard-core geology enough for G&G majors. This course needs to pick one of those sides and then double down on it (and if it goes the geology route, please rename it, because here I thought I would be learning about how energy works and not just about rock formations). I guess right now it feels most directly targeted toward those taking it as a gut science, which in my opinion is pitiful--very inconsiderate of those trying to actually learn something about the subject and to get any sort of value for their tuition.

context: I'm an econ/polisci major, already fulfilled my science requirement, took this class because I was interested in the subject itself, not to meet a requirement
That being said, I would recommend this course to someone who's interested in the subject and wants to get to know Professor Oristaglio - he is very interesting to talk to during OH and gives helpful academic/life advice. If you're looking for an easy science credit....I thought this course was relatively straightforward, but student engagement is very low, so finding a pset squad may be difficult if you're not taking it with friends who are also engaged with the material. The grades are not curved (93+ for an A), and grading gets stricter as the semester goes on. Problem sets are long, and sometimes frustrating, I liked some of them more than others, but there is something to be learned from each of them. If you've got no interest in the material itself, I'm sure you can find other easy science classes.
